title: Why is sphere considered a 3D shape? - Quora

response.answer_text: Consider a circle. If you consider the origin as an arbitrary point on the circle and name it as [math]0^\circ[/math], then we can identify all points on the circle by one co-ordinate - [math]\theta[/math]. Let’s move to a disc. For this, along with [math]\theta[/math], we will need something to measure the distance of a point under consideration from the centre of the disc, with the centre of the disc as the origin. So, we can identify all points on the disc using two co-ordinates - [math]\theta[/math] and [math]r[/math]. Now, the sphere. For this, along with [math]r[/math] and [math]\theta[/math], we will need a third co-ordinate to define the location of a point in the sphere. So, we have [math]r[/math], [math]\theta[/math] and [math]\phi[/math]. The dimensionality of an object is the minimum number of co-ordinates required to express all the elements in that object. So, that answers your question.

3 D in general means 3 dimensional like sphere has length breadth and height. Also if we keep in open space we have freedom to move in three directions i.e right-left, up-down , forward-backward so its a 3D figure. Corrections welcomed…..
